title-group.article-title: Glycemic, Insulinemic, and Appetite Responses of Patients With Type 2 Diabetes to Commonly Consumed Breads

article-meta.aff: Obesity and Immunology Research Group, Education and Research Centre, St Vincent’s University Hospital and Endocrine Unit, St Columcille’s Hospital, Dublin (Ms Breen, Dr Corrigan, Prof O’Shea)
Institute of Food & Health, University College Dublin, Belfield, Dublin, Ireland (Dr Ryan, Prof Gibney)

author-notes.corresp: Cathy Breen, BSc, Endocrine Unit, St Columcille’s Hospital, Loughlinstown, Co Dublin, Republic of Ireland (cathy.breen@ucdconnect.ie).

permissions.copyright-holder: American Association of Diabetes Educators; Published by SAGE Publications

sec.title: Purpose
sec.p: The purpose of this study was to identify the breads most commonly consumed by adults with type 2 diabetes (T2DM) and then examine the postprandial glycemic, insulinemic, and appetite responses that these breads elicit.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: One hundred people with T2DM were surveyed to identify the varieties of bread they most frequently consumed. According to a randomized crossover design, 11 fasting participants with T2DM consumed 50 g of available carbohydrate from 4 breads. Glucose and insulin concentrations and appetite ratings were determined over 270 minutes.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Three commonly consumed varieties (white, whole wheat buttermilk, whole grain) identified in the survey—plus a lower-glycemic-index “control” bread (pumpernickel rye)—were tested in the second phase. Despite perceived differences between “brown” and “white” breads, the white, whole wheat buttermilk, and wholegrain breads promoted similar glycemic and insulinemic responses. Pumpernickel bread resulted in a significantly lower peak glucose (P < .01) than all other breads and a lower peak insulin (P < .001) than white or wholegrain bread. Similar appetite responses were found with all 4 breads.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Adults with T2DM are choosing a variety of breads with perceived differential effects on glycemic, insulinemic, and appetite responses. Appreciable benefits, however, are not conferred by the commonly consumed breads. If breads known to promote favorable metabolic responses are unavailable, the primary emphasis in education should be placed on portion control. Conveying this information to patients is crucial if nutrition education is to achieve its aim of empowering individuals to manage their diabetes through their food choices.

body.p: The global epidemic of type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM), along with its associated costs and diminished quality of life, affects an estimated 366 million people worldwide.1 The disease is characterized by insulin resistance, hyperinsulinemia, pancreatic β-cell dysfunction, and elevated blood glucose (BG) levels. While a range of factors have been implicated in its etiology, overweight and obesity have emerged among the strongest modifiable risk factors associated with the development of T2DM.2 Consequently, dietary modification is considered an integral self-care behavior for successful diabetes management.3

Dietary interventions in T2DM aim to improve metabolic control and promote weight loss. While low-fat, calorie-restricted, low-carbohydrate, and Mediterranean diets are all effective for weight loss, dietary carbohydrate is the major determinant of postprandial glucose levels.4 Due to the close association that exists among postprandial glycemia, glycated hemoglobin (A1C), and the risk of diabetes-related complications,5 dietary strategies that reduce postprandial hyperglycemia and insulin demand are clearly beneficial. While monitoring the total amount of carbohydrate consumed remains a key strategy in achieving glycemic control, advocating carbohydrate foods that promote favorable glycemic and insulinemic responses provides an additional benefit.4,6 Consumption of reduced glycemic response diets are associated with favorable health outcomes7 and have been shown to significantly improve glycemic control in T2DM.8,9 Advocating carbohydrate foods with a high fiber and whole grain content is also beneficial. Intact whole grains and soluble fiber improve glycemic control and insulin sensitivity and promote satiety via slowed gastric emptying.10-12

Bread is a staple food and one of the most significant contributors to carbohydrate and energy intake worldwide.13,14 Many commercially available breads, including white, wholemeal, and seeded breads, are known to promote a high glycemic response.15 Some breads, however, have been shown to give a lower, more beneficial glycemic response, including those with a high proportion of intact grain kernels, pumpernickel rye breads, and those with added soluble fiber (β-glucan).15 -17 Unfortunately, the translation of complex nutritional science into effective food-based dietary guidance for patients is difficult. Poor translation of knowledge and evidence regarding glycemic response to foods is a significant problem and leads to propagation of misinformation in patient literature and popular media.18 Dietary messages may be simplified to discourage consumption of “white” and encourage consumption of “brown” breads without reference to their glycemic index or fiber or whole grain content. It is unclear what impact “real life” dietary advice has on the quality of breads chosen in T2DM and whether the types of breads consumed offer appreciable metabolic benefits. The aim of this study was therefore twofold: first, to identify the breads that are most commonly consumed by adults with T2DM; second, to examine the postprandial glycemic, insulinemic, and appetite responses that these breads elicit within this population.

sec.title: Study Design
sec.p: One hundred adults with T2DM completed a survey identifying the types and brands of breads they consumed most frequently. Eleven then participated in a randomized crossover study examining postprandial glycemic, insulinemic, and appetite responses to a variety of these commonly consumed breads.

sec.title: Setting and Participants
sec.p: One hundred adults with T2DM (66 men and 44 women; mean age, 65.5 ± 12.4 years; mean body mass index, 31.4 ± 5.4 kg/m2) completed the survey. They were randomly selected from the waiting areas during 2 secondary care diabetes clinics in County Dublin, Ireland. The majority were diagnosed between 1 and 10 years (64%) and managed their diabetes with lifestyle plus oral hypoglycemic agents (83%). Eleven (7 men and 4 women), recruited from the same 2 diabetes clinics, then participated in the postprandial testing phase. They were 53.9 ± 5.5 years old (mean length of diagnosis, 2.9 ± 1.5 years), obese (mean body mass index, 35.1 ± 7.5 kg/m2; waist circumference, 114.5 ± 13.4 cm), and insulin resistant (mean HOMA2-IR [updated homeostasis model assessment of insulin resistance] index, 3.94 ± 2.2). All managed their diabetes with diet and exercise alone and had a mean A1C of 45 ± 19 mmol/mol (6.3% ± 0.4%). None had a history of gastrointestinal disease or gastric surgery or were taking medications that influenced appetite or gastrointestinal function. Ten were taking a lipid-lowering agent; 9 were taking an antiplatelet agent; and 8 were taking an antihypertensive. Medications were taken as usual on study days following testing.

The study was undertaken in the Endocrine Unit at St Columcille’s Hospital and St Vincent’s University Hospital, Dublin, Ireland. Ethical approval for the study was granted by the Ethics and Medical Research Committee, St Vincent’s Healthcare Group. All participants gave written informed consent prior to participation.

sec.title: Data Collection Procedures
sec.p: Information on the breads most commonly consumed was obtained using a short questionnaire (10 questions) designed for the purposes of this study. A reference sheet with photographs of market leader brands was available to enhance brand recognition if necessary.
The 3 most commonly consumed varieties and brands from the survey were then selected for postprandial testing:

list-item.p: wheaten white—a presliced and wrapped wheaten yeast bread (Brennans White Sliced Loaf, Brennans Bakeries Ltd, Ireland);
stone-ground whole wheat buttermilk—a presliced and wrapped bread made from whole wheat flour and buttermilk (McCambridge Stoneground Wholewheat, McCambridge Ltd, Ireland); and
wheaten whole grain—a presliced and wrapped bread containing wholemeal flour and cracked wheat (Brennans Wholegrain Sliced Loaf, Brennans Bakeries Ltd, Ireland).

sec.p: While not commonly consumed, a fourth bread—pumpernickel rye (Prunte Marken Pumpernickle, Northrine-Westphalia, Germany)—was included as a “control,” as it has been shown to give a significantly lower glycemic response than that of wheaten bread.17,19 Participants attended on 4 occasions and were randomly assigned to 1 of 4 bread test meals, with a minimum of 1 week between visits. Participants were instructed to fast and refrain from exercise for 12 hours prior to testing. Participants were asked to avoid alcohol and—to minimize the second-meal effect20—avoid eating unusually large evening meals or pulses the day before testing. All breads were prepared in portions that provided 50 g of available carbohydrate, according to manufacturers’ nutritional information (Table 1). Breads were served with 250 mL of water and consumed within 10 to 15 minutes.

caption.p: Nutritional Composition of Test Bread Servings Providing 50 g of Available Carbohydrate

sec.title: Laboratory analysis
sec.p: Postprandial blood samples were taken before consuming the breads (–15 and 0 minutes) and after (15, 30, 45, 60, 90, 120, 150, 180, 210, 240, 270 minutes). Glucose concentrations were measured in capillary whole blood (per recommendations of the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations and the World Health Organization21) obtained from a finger prick sample (HemoCue Glucose 201+, HemoCue Ltd, Angelholm, Sweden). The HemoCue analyzer was calibrated daily per the manufacturer’s control solutions (Eurotrol, GlucoTrol-NG, Ede, Netherlands). Venous whole blood was collected in prechilled tubes containing EDTA/aprotinin (BD Vacutainer Systems, Plymouth, United Kingdom) and Z Serum Sep Clot Activator (Grenier, Stonehouse, United Kingdom), from an indwelling cannula in the antecubital vein. Samples were stored at −80°C. Insulin concentrations were determined with an electrochemiluminescence multiplex immunoassay (Meso Scale Discovery, Gaithersburg, Massachusetts). A1C was measured with an automated high-performance liquid chromatography instrument–reagent system (HLC-723 G7, Tosoh Europe NV, Tessenderlo, Belgium).

sec.title: Appetite
sec.p: Subjective appetite sensations were measured with a visual analogue scale (VAS) at each blood sample time point. The 4 VAS scores consisted of 100-mm-long horizontal lines, along which participants were asked to mark a vertical line at the point best corresponding to their feelings of hunger, satiety, prospective consumption, or fullness at that time. The scale was anchored at both ends with extremes of the sensation (ie, not at all hungry = 0 mm, extremely hungry = 100 mm), in accordance with established methodology.22 Participants could not refer to previous ratings when marking the VAS.

sec.title: Anthropometric measurements
sec.p: Weight was measured to the nearest 0.1 kg (Seca 665, Seca Ltd, United Kingdom) and height to the nearest 0.1 cm (Seca 242, Seca Ltd). Body mass index was calculated according to the standard formula (kg/m2). Waist circumference was measured to the nearest 0.1 cm at the midpoint between the lowest rib and the iliac crest, at the end of a normal expiration.

sec.title: Data Analysis
sec.p: Statistical analysis was performed with Graph Pad Prism 5.0 (Graph Pad Prism, San Diego, California). Results are presented as mean ± SD unless otherwise stated. The incremental area under the curve (iAUC) was calculated with the trapezoid rule, with the area below baseline ignored. Measures of insulin sensitivity were calculated as HOMA2-IR values according to the Oxford Diabetes Trials Unit calculator (see http://www.dtu.ox.ac.uk; University of Oxford, United Kingdom). Differences in responses among the 4 breads were compared via analysis of variance with post hoc analysis of significant results. Values of P < .05 were considered significant. For part 2, a sample size of 11 participants was considered sufficient on the basis of a power calculation assuming a power of 80% and an α value of 5%, with an estimated difference for insulin between an iAUC of 1000 pmol/min/L and a standard deviation of 1000 pmol/min/L.

sec.title: Commonly Consumed Breads
sec.p: Whole wheat buttermilk bread was the most commonly consumed variety (34%), followed by wheaten white and wholemeal breads (20% and 20%, respectively). Whole grain varieties were the choice of 8%, while 7% reported regularly choosing granary/multigrain breads. Eleven percent could not specify the type of bread they most commonly consumed (Figure 1).

caption.p: Percentage of respondents consuming assorted varieties and types of breads.

sec.title: Postprandial Responses
sec.p: One participant discontinued the study owing to worsening glycemic control requiring treatment with oral hypoglycemics. Results are therefore presented for the 10 participants who completed the study (Table 2). There was no significant difference in the mean fasting plasma concentrations of BG or insulin among any of the 4 test meals (Table 3).

fn.p: Abbreviation: HOMA2-IR, updated homeostasis model assessment of insulin resistance.

caption.p: Fasting and Postprandial Glucose and Insulin Responses to Test Breadsa

fn.p: Abbreviation: iAUC, incremental area under the curve.

fn.label: a
fn.p: Pvalues based on analysis of variance. Values in the same row with different subscript letters differ significantly (P < .05).

sec.p: The mean iAUC for BG was significantly lower for pumpernickel bread than for whole grain but did not differ significantly among any of the other 3 breads (Table 3, Figure 2). Peak BG concentration was similar for the white, whole wheat buttermilk, and whole grain breads but significantly lower for pumpernickel bread. At 120 minutes, BG concentration was significantly lower for pumpernickel than for white bread (153 ± 29 vs 171 ± 22 mg/dL; P = .007 [8.5 ± 1.6 vs 9.5 ± 1.2 mmol/L]) but did not differ significantly between any of the other breads (160 ± 18 and 171 ± 18 mg/dL for whole wheat and whole grain, respectively [8.9 ± 1.0 and 9.5 ± 1.0 mmol/L]) (Figure 2). BG concentration peaked at 55.5 ± 7.3 minutes for pumpernickel and 58.5 ± 4.7 minutes for whole wheat buttermilk and began to decline again within 60 minutes. This was significantly quicker (P = .001) than was the case for either the white bread (75.0 ± 15.8 minutes) or the whole grain (72.0 ± 15.5 minutes) (Figure 2).

caption.p: Glucose response curve and incremental area under the curve following consumption of test breads in part 2.

sec.p: Insulin responses (Figure 3) followed a similar pattern to that of BG. There were no significant differences in insulin iAUC or peak insulin response across white, whole wheat buttermilk, or whole grain bread. Pumpernickel gave a significantly lower iAUC and peak insulin response than did both white and whole grain bread (Table 3, Figure 3).

caption.p: Insulin response curve and incremental area under the curve following consumption of test breads in part 2.

sec.p: VAS responses for fullness and hunger are shown in Figure 4. No significant differences were observed for the iAUC for satisfaction or fullness or for the incremental area over the curve for hunger or prospective consumption, among any of the 4 breads. At 210 minutes, pumpernickel promoted a significantly greater feeling of satisfaction (P = .01) and fullness (P = .04) compared to white bread.

caption.p: Fullness and hunger ratings on a visual analogue scale following consumption of test breads in part 2.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The findings of this study show that adults with T2DM, while continuing to choose a variety of breads with perceived differential metabolic effects, are in fact choosing breads that do not offer appreciable benefits in terms of glycemia, insulinemia, or appetite.

Whole wheat buttermilk, whole grain, and white bread all promoted significant postprandial hyperglycemia (exceeding the 2-hour postmeal BG target of 140 mg/dL [7.8 mmol/L]) and hyperinsulinemia. This is deleterious because, first, postprandial hyperglycemia contributes up to 80% of A1C in well-controlled cohorts.5 Second, chronic hyperglycemia and hyperinsulinemia contribute to insulin resistance and glucotoxicity,23 resulting in decline in β-cell function and progressive deterioration in the clinical manifestations of T2DM. Given that the total amount of carbohydrate consumed has a significant influence on BG, it is prudent to limit portion size when one consumes these breads. This may reduce the degree of postprandial hyperglycemia and hyperinsulinemia evident in these results.

Whole wheat bread was shown to elicit a similar glycemic response to white bread as far back as the 1980s,24,25 but this message is clearly not reaching and affecting food choices in T2DM. Wheat-based, wrapped, and sliced whole wheat breads constitute a significant proportion of bread sales in the Western world26,27 and continue to be consumed regularly by adults with T2DM (as evidenced in the initial survey conducted). The whole wheat and whole grain bread tested had a higher fiber content than that of the white bread. A significant number of patients and health care professionals (HCPs) believe that high-fiber foods help to maintain steady BG levels,28 and this may be one of the reasons why these breads were popular. This is the case for soluble fiber10 but not insoluble fiber (the type found predominately in wheaten breads) and, as presented, is unlikely to confer glycemic advantage. Patients should be made aware of this distinction, and clear messages regarding glycemic responses to breads with a high insoluble fiber content need to be conveyed by HCPs offering dietary advice. Patient education materials should not simply state that “brown” breads are preferable; they should specify the relative benefits of foods with high soluble and insoluble fiber contents, encouraging regular consumption of vegetables, legumes, intact fruits, and whole grain cereals to meet fiber requirements.29 The addition of soluble fiber (β-glucan) to wheaten breads has been shown to improve the glycemic response,16,30 and efforts are underway to formulate breads that contain novel flours and grains that promote a lower glycemic response.31 Further food industry innovations to this end would be welcomed and would clearly need to be studied in the T2DM population.

This study highlights the limitations of using food labels to identify breads that promote a low glycemic response, most notably in the case of whole grain bread. Dietary guidelines recommend consumption of whole grain breads in T2DM.4,29 Whole grain consumption is associated with improved insulin sensitivity11 and improved glycemic response.32 However, the intact structure of the grain is essential in this regard33; breads require a high proportion of intact whole grains (typically > 50% kernels) to promote this beneficial response.15,32 This study found that the type of wheaten whole grain bread being consumed promotes a high glycemic and insulinemic response, most likely due to its refined nature and lack of intact whole grains. Breads labeled “multigrain” or “whole grain” may contain some whole grain ingredients but are primarily made with enriched wheat flour.34 The whole grain content of breads is generally not available on the label, posing a significant challenge to consumers.35 Greater regulation in this area36 and more informative labeling and promotion of breads is required to allow patients to make better choices. Manufacturers should state the percentage whole grain content of breads on the label, and dietary education in T2DM should place greater emphasis on selecting breads with a high proportion of intact whole grains.

Pumpernickel bread was included in the study as a low–glycemic index “control.” While this bread still promoted significant postprandial hyperglycemia at 120 minutes, it produced a significantly better iAUC for glucose and insulin than the wheaten breads. This is in line with findings from other studies. Jenkins and colleagues17 found a low glycemic response with pumpernickel compared to white and wholemeal bread in T2DM. Pumpernickel bread contains resistant starch, a mechanically firm and tight structure, and a considerable proportion of whole kernels—all of which may protect the starch from enzymatic hydrolysis and play a role in these beneficial responses. Pumpernickel bread is not consumed widely outside of Germany and Scandinavia but should certainly be included as an alternative to wheaten bread during T2DM dietary education.

There was no difference in reported appetite ratings among the 4 breads. Previous studies have found higher satiety responses with seeded wholemeal breads compared to white bread.37 The portions of test breads were prepared to provide 50 g of available carbohydrate, which resulted in differing bread volumes being served with varying energy and fiber contents, all of which potentially influence satiety.38 High levels of dietary restraint have been shown in overweight adults with T2DM,39 and it is possible that some underreporting of appetite occurred. Glucose and insulin fluctuations themselves influence satiety, and this relationship may be further confounded by the presence of obesity and insulin resistance.40 Further studies, designed to examine appetite responses following consumption of staple carbohydrate foods in T2DM, are required. These results, however, suggest that HCPs should be cautious about creating the expectation that commercial whole wheat or whole grain breads will promote greater satiety than white breads in T2DM. This may relate to the type of breads currently consumed; more refined grain breads promote lower satiety than do their coarser-grain counterparts,41 and soluble fiber may have a greater impact on satiety than insoluble fiber.42

Limitations to the current study include reliance on manufacturers’ information to calculate available carbohydrate. This was calculated as total carbohydrate minus dietary fiber in line with best practice.21 The breads were consumed alone, not in a “mixed meal” setting. Studies have shown, however, that the addition of fat/protein to a meal does not obscure the potential of component carbohydrate foods to predict the glycemic response.43 While the addition of toppings may have influenced the degree of postprandial hyperglycemia and hyperinsulinemia, it would not have changed the finding that responses did not differ among any of the commonly consumed breads.

sec.title: Relevance for Diabetes Educators
sec.p: Patients with T2DM continue to choose breads that do not offer appreciable benefits for glycemia, insulinemia, or appetite. HCPs continue to promote “brown” breads as preferable without reference to their glycemic index, whole grain content, or portion size—advice that is not leading to consumption of breads that promote favorable metabolic responses.

Diabetes educators need to give clear messages to patients relating to carbohydrate foods. An expectation should not be created that all whole wheat or “brown” breads with a high insoluble fiber content will promote a favorable glycemic response or promote satiety. Diabetes dietary guidelines and patient education materials should explicitly recommend breads that have been shown to promote a low glycemic response, and, if such breads are not available locally, the primary emphasis should be placed on portion control.

Diabetes educators should lobby food manufacturers to produce a greater variety of palatable, commercially available breads that promote favorable metabolic responses and to provide more informative labeling on whole grain breads, to allow patients to make more informed choices and HCPs to give accurate dietary advice.

Diabetes educators recommend avoidance of special “diabetic foods” and encourage consumption of everyday foods that the whole family can eat. To empower people to manage their diabetes through their food choices, diabetes educators must ensure that the messages and options available to patients allow them to do this.

ack.p: This work was supported by the UCD Foundation Bray Lions Club Scholarship in Diabetes. Thanks to the participants, staff of the Endocrine Unit, and CSTAR for assistance with statistical analysis.
